subject: Off to Worldcon
event: It's August, so it must be time for worldcon. (Truth be told, that sentence should read "It's Labor Day, so it must be time for worldcon, but that fight may be lost, alas, alas). The annual gathering of the tribes, our fannish family reunion. Time for rockets, time for parties, time for the fannish faithful to gather and howl at the moon. This year the gathering takes place in Kansas City, Missouri. MidAmericon II. Which just happens to be forty years after MidAmericon I in 1976, the first KC worldcon and (in my not so humble opinion) one of the best worldcons ever, and certainly the most innovative. MAC II has a lot to live up to, but I'm looking forward to a great week. All that and world class barbeque too! Burnt ends rule!!! For those of you who will be attending, here's my own schedule at the con: THURSDAY August 18 3:00 pm - 4:30 pm AUTOGRAPHING Convention Center, room 3501H FRIDAY August 19 12:00 noon - 1:00 pm READING Convention Center, room 3501H 5:00pm - 8:00 pm HIGH STAKES launch and mass Wild Cards signing, Count Basie Ballroom, Downtown Marriott (ticketed event) SATURDAY August 20 1:00 pm - 2:30 pm AUTOGRAPHING Convention Center, room 3501H 3:00pm - 5:00pm WILD CARDS Death Matches Convention Center, Tucker Stage SUNDAY August 21 11:45 am KNIGHT OF THE SEVEN KINGDOMS signing w/ Gary Gianni dealer's room, Convention Center 2:00pm - 3:00 pm panel: REMEMBERING BIG MAC I Convention Center, Tucker Stage Those are my Official Public Appearances. Mind you, I will be around for the rest of the con as well. You'll see me at parties, wandering the dealer's room, enjoying the art shows, popping into other panels, attending the Hugo Awards, drinking at the bar, eating at various local restaurants and barbeque joints. And of course, I'm always glad to say hi. Especially at those parties. Parties are the soul of worldcon. That being said, I would ask that you do NOT ask me to sign books or pose for photographs at these sorts of chance encounters. I've scheduled seven hours for autographing, spread over several days and several venues... the rest of the time I just want to enjoy the con like everyone else. (A good thing to keep in mind in dealing with ALL your favorite writers, by the way, not just me). And yes, I will be throwing another Hugo Losers Party. How not? This is the fortieth anniversary of the first one, held in my room at the old Muehlebach Hotel, the night after I lost two Hugos. But I haven't listed that here since it's not open to the general public, sorry. Invitation only. See you in KC. Let's party like it's 1976!

comments.article: Very much wish that I could make it! Do you know what you are going to read yet, or will the reading audience get a choice?

Damn I am jealous! Have a great time. Have you ever considered posting your reading at a con on your not a blog for us who want to be there but simply can't?  That way we can share in at least a small part of the experience.
comments.subject: Have a great time!

comments.article:
All the very best to you George, have a blast! We love you!

So you are going to read something on Friday. Can we hope for a new, never before revealed chapter from WINDS? (Sorry, couldn't resist.)

I think you're going to be glad you devoted not just a lot of time to your fans (which we all appreciate) but to yourself as well.  (And to your friends--your description of Hugo Losers Parties past has me so jealous.)  When I travel, I find it works best to have enough scheduled time that I feel productive but also plenty of downtime to just enjoy the experience.  And now that you've stopped most of your travel & con stuff, I'm going to guess you'll really enjoy getting to be just a fan more or less anonymously for a little while.  Have fun!
comments.subject: Sounds like a hell of a week

comments.article:
What if I haven't lost a Hugo but I am just simply a huge pitiful loser in general?

Speaking hypothetically, of course.
comments.subject: Invites?

comments.article:
Sounds like quite a time. I seriously considered making the drive that way to attend, but as I've never been to a con before and had no one to go with me, so I decided id pass. I wasn't too sure what to expect at this type of con, though the parties and all of the like minded people really tempted me.
Enjoy your time and stay safe everyone! Much love over here from Lake Powell! Perhaps I'll bring myself next time. I bet the tickets are all sold out by this point in time any how!
comments.subject: Have a grand time!

comments.article: memberships are still available in all forms at the door
comments.subject: Re: Have a grand time!

comments.article:
Having really enjoyed your reading at Balticon 50, I wondered what was the first public reading at Worldcon you ever did and what the audience's reaction was to it?

Also, any hints as to the reading on Friday afternoon?
comments.subject: Worldcon Reading

comments.article: Actually my first worldcon reading was at Big Mac I.
comments.subject: Re: Worldcon Reading

comments.article:
I believe it was at the first MidAmeriCon that we met. Somewhere around the house, I have a picture of your beautiful wife, Parris. Send her my love, and party like it's 1976!

*Kathleen McBride
comments.subject: Enjoy Big MAC 2

comments.article: So excited for my first Worldcon! Lucky enough to have a movie screening there, which is finally getting me off my butt and onto a plane! Huzzah!
I'll be there with bells on!
See you at the con. I'll be working around San Jose in 2018.
I say go as someone pretending to be you when you walk around. People would never know. Plus, you might win a costume contest.
comments.subject: costume

comments.article: See you at the con. I'll be working around San Jose in 2018.

GRRM,

I am a huge fan of the Wild Card series. Unfortunately I am unable to attend Worldcon but I would have liked to see you there and picked up a copy of High Stakes and possibly even have gotten it signed. I am extremely interested in the Wild Card Death Matches. If it is not too much trouble, can you post the results? I would love to know the outcome. Safe Travels!
comments.subject: Wild Card Death Match

comments.article: memorable person that's given you their autograph?
comments.subject: Who is the most...

comments.article:
Like the ones Nathan Fillion hands out when he wants to be left alone:

"This is to certify that I just met Nathan Fillion. How did I do?
It was great. He was impressed, and now calls you friend.
You called him Captain, and it was good.
It was friendly. We connected.
You were nervous and blushed the whole time.
You interrupted his dinner task for a photo.
There are charges pending."
comments.subject: Why not hand out cards?

comments.article: Mr. Martin, you may already know about this place, but if not, Joe's Kansas City BBQ is the absolute best. Arthur Bryant's is also amazing, but I've never had brisket like Joe's (formerly called Oklahoma Joe's). The brisket melts in your mouth, the fries are addictive, and the burnt ends are to die for! The original is still out of a gas station which should be an indication-less pretense, better BBQ!
comments.subject: BBQ Recommendation!!

comments.article:
Hello Mr. Martin!

Just curious if you will be attending the presentation of the John W. Campbell Memorial Award tonight at MAC II.

One of the titles our small publishing house (The Permanent Press in Sag Harbor, NY) published last year titled Radiomen by Eleanor Lerman has been nominated as a finalist for the award. It is certainly one of my most favorite books that we have ever done, and it is certainly deserving of this honor as it is a uniquely literary science fiction novel that is equal parts fantastical and biting satire. Should it win tonight, I'm sure even a single word from someone such as yourself would launch the stature of this small house to astronomical levels.

Enjoy the con!
Best regards,
Brian
comments.subject: The John W. Campbell Memorial Award

comments.article: Q39 is the best new BBQ joint in town. Stop in or get it to go; you won't be disappointed.  Enjoy your time in KC!
comments.subject: Q 39

comments.article:
Hi, George!

I'm sorry to ask you this here, I know it's off-topic but it's something I'm really curious about and I didn't know where else I could ask you this. I just want to know if there's gonna be a Melisandre's PoV chapter in The Winds of Winter, I loved her chapter in ADwD and I was sad to see it was her only chapter in the book. Thank you!
comments.subject: Melisandre

comments.article:
I must say, I just found this blog and it is incredibly interesting! I lost a few hours around these! Is this George R.R. Martin the writer himself? Is this really you?



I do not know where to ask. Is there any chance to see some updates to the "what i'm reading " section ? Lately I have reread your books and in some way it depresses me just how good they are...no matter what other stuff I read it is less interesting.

I have read most recommendations of yours. Some other books that I really like are: The Second Apocalypse by R Scott Bakker ( criminally underrated) Anything by Wolfe and the Malazan series by Erikson.(maybe one day I will read what you think about these!)

Anyway...this comment is bringing out the fanboy in me, the thought of my favorite author actually reading this is amazing!

I loved reading your posts and I hope one day you will continue the lists, I find your opinions and suggestions really interesting. Greetings from Eastern Europe!

I just have an image in my head of crowds of people at Worldcon avoiding all human contact reading a tattered paperback and then furiously posting on message boards arguing if science fiction or fantasy is the better genre. Anyway, have fun at your convention.

Congratulations to all of the winners. And congratulations to those who now get to party with GRRM at the Losers Party.

Since the puppies and their slates were soundly defeated again, can we have Hugo Awards now without slates? Do it the old-fashioned way and nominate what you like and then vote for those nominees you liked the most? No more slates, just the Hugo Awards. For those who can't deal with that simple idea, you are free to start your own awards instead of trying to destroy the Hugos.

I spent the day in KC attending lots of great panels, perusing the vendors, and getting in some real quality people-watching time. I saw your post about it months ago and it inspired me to read the Hugo nominees and treat myself with a day pass. So, a very big thank you for bringing it to my attention!
comments.subject: First Worldcon Under My Belt

comments.article: What did you end up reading on friday, if you dont mind me asking? B.t.w. i loved the Aeron ch.
comments.subject: Worldcon reading
